column65: Comment/Editorial

Nine deputies were fired from the sheriff's office in May amid internal investigations into Ajibade's death, and three others left the department earlier. Two have been indicted on related charges including falsification of logs and records. According to the autopsy report, Ajibade died from 'blunt force trauma ' a combination of abrasions, lacerations, skin injuries about the head and some other areas of the body.'

Roberto Ornelas succumbed to "delayed complications of acute drug toxicity," the Miami-Dade County Medical Examiner Department wrote in a report. Investigators are not sure what kind of drug Ornelas took. It is listed on the report as an "unknown substance." Officers arrived when Roberto was destroying his room and his father called police. Father and police say he was incoherent, erratic and speaking in tongues, with blood on the walls of his room.
Officer responding to an alarm at a business at around 4 a.m. when he struck Gagne who was lying in the road on a darkened stretch. No autopsy released as of June 2015

911 received four calls stating the suspect was under the influence of alcohol and armed with a knife. Officers arrived and say Quintero was belligerent and confrontational. After being told to show his hands Quintero allegedly threatened officers.  Ordered to place hands on the SUV, Quintero refused, officers say. Officers TASED but innefective. Officer fired two rounds from .223 patrol rifle. POlice say Quintero allegedly 'was armed with a knife and began threatening to kill individuals in the residence.'and "allegedly put a knife to a 21-year-old woman's throat, and one witness told police he had assaulted his father with the knife before the two men went to the SUV." Two witnesses disgree and say Quintero's hands were up and he was not facing the officer who shot him. Autopsy sayd COD from two gunshot wounds, one to his 'upper medial left buttock' and the other in his 'lateral left buttock'. He suffered extensive internal injuries, underwent surgery and went into cardiopulmonary arrest and couldn't be revived, the autopsy report says. Quinterotested positive for alcohol, methamphetamine and marijuana, autopsy report also listed 'blunt force' injuries on his head, neck, back and extremities

Michael Kocher Jr. was struck by a Toyota, whose driver called police, Officer Irvin Magayanes responded and on arriving at the scene, hit Kocher with his patrol vehicle, and Kocher died at the scene. Magayanes was charged with second-degree negligent homicide

Pickett's mother called LAPD to report her son was under the influence of drugs and threatening her life; officers arrived and described Picket as agressive; he was TASED and cuffed. When paramedics arrived to remove TASER darts he became unresponsive and died.

Steele and her husband, Gabriel Steele were in a domestic dispute and the officer was trying to break it up. Witnesses report that the dog attacked the officer suddenly and the officer fired, missed and killed Steele. The AP reported that the County Attorney said her decision not to charge the officer was supported by body camera evidence, witness statements and reports from the Iowa Division of Criminal Investigation. The officer had to make an instantaneous decision as the threat was occurring, Bevers said. The officer was treated for dog bite.

Officers responded to a motel to complaints of Murphy causing a disturbance, and had a range of physical interactions including an attempted but apparently failed TASER exposure and fighting (PKIC CONSIDERS THIS A DEPLOYMENT). Toxicology reports indicate there were high levels of methamphetamine in Murphy's system, which was within a range that most toxicologists would say would be toxic, police said. K-2 was also found in his system.

Police responded to an alarm at a pharmacy to find a burglary in process. A deputy arrived on the scene and found Howard inside the store. KNOE reports that a struggle ensued for control of the deputy's weapon, and it went off, shooting Howard. The deputy handcuffed Howard and upon noticing the injury called an ambulance.

Lauderhill police were investigating a stolen vehicle.  They confronted Demaris Turner in a stolen Hyundai Genesis; Turner rammed the car into a marked K-9 cruiser, which had an officer and a K-9 inside, deputies said. An officer fired into the car; Local10.com says that Turner was hit 11 times.

Haynes an envelope in his hand that the deputies were trying to examine; when Haynes refused, the coroner says, "There was some type of interaction that led to some type of a confrontation with multiple deputies."

Hernandez, 17, was driving a stolen car with four teenaged passengers to flee from officers when she attempted to strike with the car an officer trying to stop her. That officer fired, killing her; witnesses disputed the officers' statement however the district attorney notes the coroner states, "The locations of the bullet strikes from Officer Jordan's gunshots are consistent with his description of being extremely close to the car, pushing off of the car with his left hand, and shooting at the driver with a downward trajectory as the Honda was moving forward, with the gun in his right hand." Ruled justified.

Officer Lisa J. Mearkle stopped Kassick for o inspection sticker; Kassick fled and Mearkle TASED him and ordered him to show his hands; Kassick is said to have hidden one hand under his body and Mearkle shot him twice in the back. Mearkle was charged with criminal homicide after investigators concluded she shot Kassick twice on Feb. 2 without legal justification. Kassick had drugs and alcohol in his system and a syringe.

Officer David Stith responded to a burglary call and encountered Lett on the 911 caller's front porch with his hand in his pocket; Stith approached Lett with his weapon drawn shouting, "Tallahassee Police! Show me your hands!" Lett yelled and tried to tackle Stith multiple times; Stith attempted to use his taser on Lett but it didn't work and even shocked Stith in the rain; Stith was tackled and pinned to the ground by Lett and that is when he fired his gun, killing Lett; ME says COD five gunshot wounds to the torso and left upper arm; Lett had cocaine in his system at TOD; Leon County grand jury found Stith was justified in his use of deadly force

US Marshal's Service Task Force, Terre Haute PD sought Long for multiple rape and kidnapping charges; when attempting to •box in the suspect vehicle with police vehicles' the suspect began ramming police vehicles; Long inserted his right hand inside of his •heavy winter coat' at which point he was TASED ineffectively; as he withdrew his hand he was shot by police. Judged justified.

Lewis was driving a vehicle that refused to stop when ordered by police, then turned and drove toward officers, who fired at the vehicle. When it stopped officers saw Lews had been shot, fatally wounded.
Ernesto Canepa was sitting in a vehicle that matched that of a man who had robbed a gold chain from a woman earlier. Police have not released details but a replica BB gun was found in the vehicle
An autopsy showed Sharrer had deadly levels of methamphetamine in his system. He also suffered from heart disease and emphysema. Had been pepper sprayed on admission to jail for non compliance

Sgt. Jonathan Frost stopped Guilford after Guilford flashed his brights at Frost's vehicle to (erroneously) warn Frost that his brights were on. Frost effectEd stop on PC that Guilford used brights within 500 ft. Guilford argued he did nothing and refused to produce license and insurance. the argument continued as Guilford got out of the car and Frost went to arrest, Guilford resisted. Frost TASED Guilford but did not get good contact; the two grappled and rolled into a ditch; Frost said Guilford was stop him and punching him when Frost fired several times. DA ruled this justified after reviewing video and statements

column65: It is unclear whether McIntire was killed by the vehicle; video shows him staggering before the vehicle arrived, and he had a history os passing out drunk in the road

The Counted said, ñJeffries was reportedly intoxicated and urinating in public. When an officer arrived, he refused to take a breathalyzer test and leaned on a patrol car, according to police. The two entered into an altercation and JeffriesÍ head hit the car, breaking his neck. Jeffries died two weeks later in hospital.î To this, WVMetroNews only adds, ñOfficer Eric Riddle was suspended pending an investigation, but was cleared by an internal investigation conducted by the Weston Police Department. He returned to work one week after the incident in question.î

ñAs Broyles arrived on the scene, he saw Judson fleeing, pulled his patrol car into a parking lot, parked it and gave chase on foot. Berry said during a foot chase the suspect ignored repeated commands to ñstopî and ñget on the ground.î The deputy fired his stun gun, but it failed to stop the suspect. According to Berry, the video shows the suspect getting into the deputyÍs patrol car. The two struggled for control of the car; the deputy drew his handgun and continued to order the man to give up. Berry said the suspect tried to put the car into gear. Witnesses said they heard the carÍs engine rev. During the struggle for the car, the suspectÍs hand was near the deputyÍs loaded AR-15-style rifle, which was mounted in the car, Berry said. The suspect then tried to drive off with the deputyÍs hand stuck in the door. Broyles then made the decision to open fire. The first shot hit Judson in the left arm and went into his chest. Broyles managed to free himself from the car as Judson put the car into reverse. BroylesÍ second shot hit the door jam. The car crashed into an electrical tower. Broyles fired two more times. One bullet hit the passengerÍs door. The other struck Judson in the head. Judson died at the scene. ñDeputy Broyles at the time he fired his weapon was reasonably in fear for his own life. He too, reasonably believed that to allow Judson to flee in the patrol vehicle, based on all that had transpired, could pose a significant threat to the communityƒî

In this case, there are very few facts to discuss, and The CountedÍs report is extremely straightforward: ñSqueiros died from a heart attack following a physical altercation with police, who were responding to a report that he was causing a disturbance. Police said he became combative and had to be restrained. SiqueirosÍs sister and a neighbour said that a large group of officers had been on top of him during the struggle.î NBC Los Angeles reports (and this is in the video, not the written story accompanying the video) that an unnamed witness, ñthe neighbor who called authoritiesî who ñdid not want to go on camera but said that Siqueiros was, ñacting strangelyî and that his eyes were glazed over. Police ordered him to the ground and the man who called in the authorities said that the arest was orderly and not forceful.î NBC continues, ñSiqueiros allegedly ñbecame combativeî when police arrived, and officers took him into custody, police said. While in custody, Siqueiros went into cardiac arrest and later died at the hospital, police said.î

NBC Bay Area reports, ñPolice said they found Deming just after 2 a.m. when responding to a burglary alarm at Specialty Sales Classics, a car dealership at 4321 First St. The Counted tells the story thusly: ñPolice were responding to a burglar alarm when authorities said they encountered Deming inside a business acting ïagitated and aggressiveÍ. According to police, they attempted to use beanbag rounds to subdue Deming before he escaped through back window, where officer Daniel Kunkel began following him. Police say the two wound up in a physical altercation after KunkelÍs Taser failed to stop Deming, who wound up on top of the officer, ïpummeling his headÍ. Kunkel claimed he was afraid he would lose consciousness and fired his weapon once at DemingÍs torso and again at his face when the initial shot failed to stop the attack.î Apparently the crime involved malicious mischief: according to ABC7, ñSpecialty Sales Classics salesman Jeremy Bolen says the hood of a 1967 Mustang was scrawled on with a sharpie. The suspect even walked on a Cadillac worth $115,000. ñYou canÍt repaint this,î he explained. ñThereÍs a bunch of other damage. Graffiti in the bathroom,î he added.î NBC Bay Area continues, ñInitially police said Deming was found in front of the business, but clarified Tuesday he was still inside but could be seen through the dealershipÍs large front windows. Deming allegedly threw a 50-pound floor jack through the window, which landed on the sidewalk near the officers. Police fired at him with a beanbag round but missed, and Deming refused commands to leave the dealership, police said.î Deming then ran out the back through a broken window. NBC continues, ñ[Officer Daniel] Kunkel was standing watch in the back of the business and saw Deming jump through the broken window. Kunkel ordered him to stop but Deming kept running, and Kunkel hit him in the back with a Taser, according to police. The Taser didnÍt stop Deming, and Kunkel started to chase him until Deming turned and charged Kunkel aggressively, police said Deming allegedly kicked Kunkel in the stomach and punched him in the head, knocking him to the ground. Deming got on top of Kunkel, pummeling his head as he lay on the concrete, police said. Kunkel thought he might lose consciousness and used his Taser again, but again it had no effect, so he drew his pistol and shot Deming once in the torso. However, even that didnÍt stop Deming and he continued his attack, police said. Kunkel then fired two more rounds, hitting Deming at least once in the face, police said.î

ñPolice were responding to reports of a prowler in the neighborhood but have provided little details on the the circumstances before AndersonÍs death. AndersonÍs wife said her husband had been fixing a bicycle near the house the homeless couple had been squatting in, but fled when police arrived due to a fear of being caught trespassing. Anderson jumped a fence and was then shot in the torso,î said The Counted. Details on this incident are unclear, and there is suspicion about why Anderson was shot. KTLA reported that, ñA 911 caller reported a man was knocking on his or her door and attempting to get inside the house, located in the 12200 block of 216th Street (map), around 9:40 p.m. Sunday.î NBC Los Angeles reported, ñThe family said Johnny Ray Anderson was knocking on the homeÍs door because he wanted to escape authorities, but authorities said on Sunday that deputies came after the report of a prowler.î

column8: Lacey Rd and Deerhead Lake Dr
column65: The Counted notes that, ñWhile crossing a street, Van De Putte was struck by a police patrol car being driven by an officer who was responding to an unrelated call. Authorities said Van De Putte was walking against the traffic signal.î This is another horrible accident that seems to be added to this database for the purposes of inflating the numbers. But in this case, it is so obviously biased against the officer that it neglects even in its brief description to mention that it was 3:40 am at the time of the accident, and it mischaracterizes as ñauthorities saidî a witness report stating that Mr. van de Putte was crossing against the signal, and neglects entirely to mention that the officer tried to avoid Mr. van de Putte to the extent that he crashed his patrol car into a utility pole. The Asbury Park Press reported, ñLacey Police Officer Andrew Slota was responding to a call and traveling East on Lacey Road when his patrol car struck Vandeputt before veering off the road and into a utility pole following an evasive maneuver by the officer. Witnesses to the incident indicated that Vandeputt was crossing against the traffic signal to the north of Lacey Road at the Deerhead Lake intersection when he was struck by Slotta, [Ocean County ProsecutorÍs Office spokesman Al] Della Fave said. According to Della Fave, though Slota attempted to avoid Vandeputt, the pedestrian was struck by the front passenger side of the patrol vehicle, and after impact the vehicle struck a utility pole on the westbound side of the road, eventually coming to rest in the bank parking lot adjacent to the roadway. Vandeputt was pronounced dead at the scene by Dr. Konomos from Newark Beth Israel at 3:47 a.m. Slota was taken to Community Medical Center where he was treated for non-life threatening injuries.î

Mr Gormley was killed by the Utah State patrol when he suffered a heart attack after being TASED four times. As The Counted tells it, ñGormley suffered a heart attack after being shocked with a Taser four times during a struggle with a trooper, according to authorities. After eluding capture by police several times in the preceding few days, following his escape from a jail work-release scheme, he beat an elderly woman and attempted to steal her car in an effort to escape from the trooper. He was placed into a coma in hospital but died a week later.î The important thing to note here is that officers attempted to protect Mr Gormley using less-lethal force despite the circumstances of his chase and subsequent arrest. And this is a great example of how context is important_„_as horrible as that Counted account makes Gormley sound, reality is much, much worse. Mr. Gormley had in fact been, as The Counted says, on work-release from jail (where he was serving time on a retail theft conviction); the 30 year old had escaped, then after stealing a motorcyle and getting stopped by the state police on a traffic charge, Gormley used the motorcycle to escape again. Gormley then stole a car from Wasatch Front Kia. According to FOX13, police, ñwent to the apartment where GormleyÍs girlfriend lives near 24th St. and D Ave. in Ogden. They saw him jump from the apartment window and speed off in her car. Troopers chased Gormley to 21st St., where they boxed him in but he ran from the car and tried to carjack others. Authorities said he tried to carjack a truck and trailer but didnÍt get in.î Then, according to KSL.com, ñInvestigators looking for Gormley found him Monday. He attempted to escape by jumping into a car driven by a 53-year-old woman. He punched, scratched and bit the woman in an attempt to get her out of the car, according to the UHP. Troopers used Tasers on Gormley four times before taking him into custody. After he was handcuffed, shackled and taken out of the car, Gormley went into cardiac arrest, according to the UHP. Gormley was taken to McKay-Dee Hospital Center where he was placed in a medically induced coma.î He later died. KSL continues, ñTests showed [Gormley] was under the influence of methamphetamine and opiates at the time.î FOX13 reports that the medically induced coma was necessary precisely because of the amount of methamphetamine in GormleyÍs system.

The Counted reports, ñAn attorney for SandersÍs family said an officer choked him to death with a flashlight. But police chiefs denied this, and said he sustained injuries during a physical fight involving no weapons. Sanders had been exercising his horse before the encounter with the officer, according to his family.î The Clarion-Ledger reported, "We donÍt know why he was going after Jonathan, we donÍt know what the reason for stopping him was, we donÍt know what led up to this incident,î Parish said, adding that he hasnÍt been able to talk to all the eyewitnesses yet. ThatÍs when an altercation occurred.  Details are sketchy by all accounts. Early reports had Herrington using a flashlight to strangle Sanders, but both Street and Parish have since said there was no flashlight. Parish said as far as he knows, Sanders did not have a weapon, but that Sanders ended up strangled to death.î The Associated Press later reported, ñStonewall Police Chief Michael Street said he has turned the inquiry over to the Mississippi Bureau of Investigation, as is typical when a police officer is involved in someoneÍs death in Mississippi. Warren Strain, the spokesman for MBI, said an autopsy has been completed and that SandersÍ body has been returned to his family. He said MBI has notified the FBI, which he described as ñoffering support.î Strain said autopsy results are being analyzed and he canÍt release a cause of death. Street and Mitchell said MBI is likely to hold a news conference in coming days to discuss the autopsyÍs findings. Strain described the encounter between Herrington and Sanders as a physical ñaltercation."

ñAccording to the [Georgia Bureau of Investigation], officers responded around 4:15 a.m. on July 11 to a call reporting an individual acting ñcrazyî in the callerÍs garage at 5100 Rock Place Drive in unincorporated Stone Mountain. The caller said ñhis male neighbor was locked in his garage, was irate and possibly armed.îî The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported that, ñOfficers made contact with the man and ñan altercation ensued,î Doan said. ñThe suspect went unresponsive at the scene and was transported to Eastside Medical Center where he was pronounced dead,î Doan said.î The Georgia Bureau of Investigation told the Gwinnett Daily Post that, ñMann was stunned with the taser when he resisted the officers and went unresponsive at the scene. He was transported to Eastside Medical Center where he was pronounced dead.î Neither The Counted nor the AJC mentioned, but the GBI did note, that ña gun and suspected methamphetamine were found in the garage where Mann was [arrested]î according to the Daily Post.

The Counted explains that, ñAn officer said he fatally shot Ellswood after the man punched him in the face during an evening encounter behind a doctorsÍ office building that he was patrolling. Police said the veteran officer, who had asked Ellswood to leave, first used his Taser but that it was ineffective.î This would appear to be relatively straightforward attack on a police officer. The officer reportedly attempted to end the assault on his person with a less-lethal solution_„_the TASER_„_and when that failed and the attack did not stop, the officer fired, killing the man. Plantation police Detective Philip Toman told media including Local10 that Ellswood, ñhad an extensive arrest record, including acts of violence towards law enforcement officers. He also had an active warrant out for his arrest.î

The Counted states, ñStafford was arrested for trying to sell stolen puppies. After arriving at the county jail for booking, a ïbrief physical altercationÍ occurred and Stafford became unconscious, according to police. He died after officers attempted to render medical assistance, according to police.î The Burlington Times-News reported that, ñ...there was a brief scuffle as 55-year-old Bruce Dean Stafford was being booked into the jail and Stafford collapseD....[J]ail staff as well as Hendersonville firefighters and the county EMS tried to revive Stafford. He was taken to Pardee Hospital where he was pronounced dead.î The Henderson Lightning reports, ñThe officer ñwas wearing a camera on his chestî that recorded all his interaction with Stafford. SBI agents have already interviewed Underwood and his supervisor, Simonds said, and the police department has turned over the camera footage to the state agency. Cameras in the jail also would have recorded the booking process.î Stealing puppies?

The Counted says, ñBrown was turning on to a main street, driving a van. He was killed after being struck by an SUV being driven at high speed by a sheriffÍs deputy. Authorities said the deputy was pursuing a separate suspected drunk-driver who had just narrowly avoided crashing into the SUV before speeding away.î While this accounts notes the high speed, I canÍt help but note that it does not include the undisputed fact that the deputy had his lights and sirens on. Witnesses state this was a horrible accident. The Columbus Dispatch reports, ñBud BrownÍs van was pulling out from a KeyBank parking lot on the south side of Sullivant just west of Demorest Road when it was struck on the driverÍs side by the eastbound deputyÍs SUV, said Columbus Police Sgt. Brooke Wilson of the accident-investigation unit.î WBNS TV elaborates, ñHe exited in front of the cruiser and turned in front of the cruiser. The cruiser struck the driverÍs side of the van,î said Columbus Police Sgt. Brooke Wilson. ñThe van actually rotated 360 degrees across the street and came to rest where you see it now. During the rotation of the van, the driver was ejected.îƒ ñObviously our thoughts and prayers are with this individual,î added Franklin Couty Chief Deputy Jim Gilbert. ñThis is somebodyÍs father. This is somebodyÍs family member. And obviously our concerns are with that family.î

ñDavis was involved in a ïvery, very violentÍ struggle with an officer, according to police. The officer had been called after reports of a fight in the area involving five men. The officer deployed his Taser and then fired his gun once, striking Davis. Davis later died in hospital,î reports The Counted. The Orlando Sentinel gives this account : ñOrlando police were called to the apartment complex near the intersection of Curry Ford Road and South Conway Road after a fight broke out among five people, including Davis. When Vidro tried to arrest Davis, he took off running but was caught about 100 yards away. Instead of surrendering, Davis chose to fight with the officer, [Police Chief John] Mina said. ñBased on the physical evidence at the scene and radio transmissions, it appears there was a very, very violent struggle there,î Mina said. ñOur officer did use his Taser at some point during the struggle and a lot of his equipment, to include his Taser, baton, gun magazine, wristwatch and ball cap, were strewn about the scene of this violent struggle.î Mina said Vidro fired his gun one time, hitting Davis in the chest. Police attempted CPR until paramedics arrived. Davis was taken to a local hospital, where he was first listed in critical condition, then later died.î

The Counted reports that, ñStewart was traveling in a vehicle that was stopped by police for a broken headlight. Authorities said he was placed in the back of a patrol car, unhandcuffed, while officers ran his name. When the officers returned to handcuff Stewart and take him into custody for outstanding warrants, police said he became combative and struck an officer with the handcuffs. The officer then drew his gun and fired. StewartÍs mother told local news that her son had never been arrested and that the warrants were for someone else with the same name.î WMC Television reported that, ñInvestigators said when the officer opened the back door to handcuff Stewart, he kicked the door and attacked the officer.î I note that if the account is correct and the officer was moving to handcuff Stewart, then the officer would presumably have received, or believed he had received, confirmation on the arrest warrants, which WMC states were for a sexual offense in Iowa and another offense in Illinois. WMC continues, ñDuring the fight, Stewart grabbed the officerÍs handcuffs and swung them at him. The officer grabbed his gun and shot Stewart to end the fight. Stewart went to Regional Medical Center in critical condition where he later died. The officer had several cuts and bruises from the fight, but he did not need to go to the hospital. He is relieved of duty pending the outcome of this investigation.î The Memphis Flyer identified the officer as 26-year-old Connor Schilling, and noted that ñSchilling, who worked in the MPDÍs Ridgeway precinct, had a previous suspension for a DUI arrest in Southaven in July 2014 , but criminal charges were dismissed in that case. He did, however, receive departmental charges after the incident. His personnel file also contains one excessive force case in 2013 that was found to be not sustained by the MPD.î

WHBQ Memphis reports that Goode, ñwithout explanation got out of the car and apparently started acting in an erratic fashion to attract the attention from a bystander, and they called Southaven Police.îƒ Southaven Police say they believe Goode was on LSD. Police told FOX13 the 30-year-old was restrained and taken to Baptist DeSoto where he later died. GoodeÍs attorney told FOX13 he has lots of questions about what happened between the time Goode left the scene and the time GoodeÍs wife got the call two hours later. ñWe know that he was hogtied and we know that he was placed face down on a stretcher, and we know a witness said he heard him say ïI canÍt breathe.Í We know he is an asthmatic and used an inhaler,î the police said. WHBQ continued by saying, ñWe have also learned that the act of ñhogtieingî someone during arrest is used on a statewide level by law enforcement in Mississippi. It can be used by officers if a suspect could kick or otherwise injure an officer or EMT worker while being taken into custody.î

The account by Officer Ray Tensing of the traffic stop was later disproved by body camera footage released by Cincinnati prosecutor Joseph Deters, who announced that murder charges were being filed against University of Cincinnati police officer Ray Tensing.î The Guardian later reported, ñTensing had maintained he was ñdraggedî by DuBoseÍs vehicle after the two entered into a physical altercation and was forced to shoot, but Hamilton County prosecutor Joseph Deters said body-camera evidence completely contradicted this account. In a frank assessment of the officerÍs conduct, Deters said Tensing had ñpurposely killedî DuBose and that he ñshould never have been a police officerîî Fox News reports that ñDeters says the shooting of motorist Samuel DuBose in a ñchicken crapî stop over a missing front license plate was ñasinine,î and ñwithout question a murder.î He also said the university shouldnÍt be in the policing business at all. The prosecutor said he thinks now-fired Officer Ray Tensing lost his temper because DuBose wouldnÍt get out of the carî.
Officer stated many facts that video disproved; charged with murder 1 and voluntary manslaughter

ñThe St. Clair Shores police officer was eastbound on Eight Mile approaching Intestate 94 when he saw a vehicle pass in the opposite direction with no headlights on, state police Lt. Calvin Hart told MLive Detroit. The officer made a U-turn and began heading west. While following the vehicle in preparation to make a traffic stop, the other vehicle turned left off Eight Mile into a driveway and the officer followed, at which point Bush crashed into the front-passenger side of the police car.î Police Chief Todd Woodcox told the Macomb Daily, ñWe cannot undo the tragedy, but we can promise a full and complete investigation into the circumstances surrounding the crashî

ñA preliminary investigation determined that two people were trying to subdue the man when Therkelsen arrived. The man did not immediately submit to TherkelsenÍs demands, and she used her Taser on the suspect, which did not subdue him. When Therkelsen tried to physically subdue him, a fight ensued and the suspect tried to grab her gun from her holster. Therkelsen regained the weapon, and fatally shot the man.î The Minneapolis Star-Tribune reported after an interview with WolfstetterÍs father, ñOne day before the Plymouth incident, police were called to WolfstellerÍs grandparentsÍ home for a mental health crisis, but his father said Monday that police couldnÍt take him to the hospital against his will.î They add about the incident two important details: first, ñan ArbyÍs employee [had] called 911 about a disturbance and, Duane Wolfsteller said, several restaurant employees tackled his son to the ground.î Second, ñThe BCA said that, according to the preliminary investigation, officer Amy Therkelsen responded to a report of a disturbance, and was told on the way that the man had a weapon and was inside the restaurant. When she arrived, two people were attempting to subdue Wolfsteller. When he didnÍt immediately follow her commands, she used her Taser, but it proved ineffective, investigators said.î Plymouth Police Chief Michael Goldstein saidƒhis department had had previous contact with Wolfsteller. He declined to elaborate.î

White was waiting outside the home of a female deputy, ñallegedly hiding behind a vehicleî when she returned to her home in the middle of the night. White, ñran out towards her and attacked. The sheriff said Oakley attempted to subdue White with a Taser before shooting him.î According to WCRB TV, White ñtackled her and they got in a scuffle and he took his hands and put them around her face and tried to kill her,î Sheriff Eric Watson said. The deputy attempted to TASE White, which was unsuccessful in stopping the attack, before resorting to deadly force by shooting him. Sheriff Watson added, ñHe was clearly on her property and close to her front door.î

Delgado-Soba died after he was shocked with a Taser ñafter allegedly charging at police in a grocery store. Officers had been called when Delgado-Soba entered the store shirtless and began knocking items of shelves, according to police, who stressed that he was given several verbal warnings.î The Worcester Telegram reports that Delgado-Soba had entered the store and begun smashing glass and throwing things. The store owner, Mike Maranda, said ñpolice ñtried everythingî before using the Taser.îƒ ñMrs. Maranda said the officers did not strike the man in any way. ñThey tried very hard to talk to him,î she said, noting the man had resisted them by swinging his arms and hands.î The Telegram, which links to the police scanner recording, notes that dispatchers told the responding officers, ñHeÍs destroying the store, and heÍs got a couple bottles in his hands.î Mr Delgado-Soba had convictions for, among other things, assault with a dangerous weapon, breaking and entering in the daytime with intent to commit a felony, assault and battery and intimidation of a witness

Raiwaya, who was 6 feet tall and 265 pounds, was the caregiver to 96 year-old Solomon Cohen, who was badly beaten before 5 a.m. that day and was not expected to survive his head injuries. Raiyawa rear-ended a BMW, pushing it across the street and into parked car, according to the San Francisco Chronicle. The victim in the crash got out to talk to Raiyawa. The victim backed away, police said, and called 911 as Raiyawa got out of his car and approached him in a threatening manner, eventually chasing him around the block. When police responded, Raiyawa beat a female officer several times about the head and shoulders, beating her to the ground nearly unconscious, and throwing her partner by the wrist,î Suhr said. Willie Gunnari, 35, who lives on Lombard, said he saw the two female police officers trying to subdue the suspect. Gunnari said the man resisted, flailing his arms as the officers hit him with batons. ñNothing was going to get him to stop moving,î Gunnari said. Witnesses reported that Raiyawa ignored repeated commands to get on the ground, and to stop resisting, and collapsed after he tried to break into a restaurant
Rushed into Dallas County jail agitated and was subdued by Deputy; witnesses say aggressively.
Ran from officer on traffic stop, fell from 8' wall
Officer in training fired on Taylor.
Russo weighed in excess of 400 lbs

column8: Marlboro Pike and Walker Mill Rd
column65: Police state Manley had been expressing suicidal thoughts. "Despite being wounded, the man continued to fight with the officer and was not restrained until a second officer used a Taser on Manley multiple times, police said" - WaPo
TASED  multiple times but continued to approach officers

column12: Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department, Baldwin Park Police Department
column65: suspect had stolen a large American flag and flag pole from a gas station and had been swinging it at cars and people in the area

Homicide warrant for his arrest; this incident disrupted a second homicide; this man was 2nd of three fugitives wanted for homicide and was in car with a woman police describe as a "next victim"; Police initially claimed Jacquez was "reaching for his wasitband" later retracted this statement and stated Jacquez was shit in the back fleeing from police
Tried to drive away from officer during resisting arrest; Known to officer who killed him as being wanted for theft.

column12: Scottsdale Police Department, Phoenix Police Department
column65: 911 caller reported man was "on drugs"

According to initial reports, a southbound Honda Civic driven by a 37-year-old woman made a left turn into the path of a northbound police department Ford Explorer, which hit the Civic in the front passenger door. Alcohol found in car, driver admits drinking
Kumi was caught in crossfire as police fired at suspects in an undercover gun buying operation.
